Those concepts, I’ll write on the board, and then we’ll take some time to define them. They include the concept of inspiration, the concept of infallibility, and the concept of inerrancy. Now, before I go into a development of these concepts here, I’d like you to just think within the quiet chambers of your own mind, what are your personal reactions to these concepts? What do you think of when you hear the word inspiration, and what goes through your mind when you think of the term infallible? And perhaps most importantly, how do you react viscerally to the term inerrant, or inerrancy? I ask these questions for a reason. There is a tremendous amount of emotion that casts a pall over each and all of these terms, and sometimes I find it in theology somewhat difficult for people to get past the emotion to examine carefully the content that is contained in these words. F or example, when I was in... in seminary, if somebody used the term inerrancy with respect to the Scripture that immediately categorized that person as being a back woods fundamentalist with no education whatsoever. The normal response would be, “How could anybody believe in the inerrancy of Scripture in this day and age after two hundred years of profound academic analysis and scholarly criticism?” And so, the term inerrancy emerges something of a shibboleth. As a word that became a passport for orthodoxy or opposed to orthodoxy, and so on. This issue became so severe that in the late seventies an organization was formed in America that included scholars from around the world. Several hundred of them as a matter of fact, but under the leadership of an executive committee of fifteen or sixteen of them to study the question of the authority, the inspiration, the infallibility, the inerrancy of the Bible. And this organization was called the International Council on Biblical Inerrancy. And it devoted itself not only to ten years of study, but also of publications of various sorts and several conferences. And the first summit meeting of this organization was held in Chicago in 1978 when several hundred people came together and discussed and debated various issues about the integrity of Scripture. And what emerged from that event was a document that included a united statement on Scripture and then, a lengthier document that included affirmations, twenty-some affirmations and denials about Scripture. That is, careful definitions saying, “We affirm that the Bible is this, this, and this. We deny that it is this, this, and this.” So that it would be as clear as possible what was being stated on the matter. I was asked to write a commentary for the ICBI event on that document of affirmations and denials, and in brief form, so that the lay person could have it, and read through it and be educated and informed about some of these very subtle questions regarding sacred Scripture. We have these always available, it’s called, Explaining Inerrancy, a Commentary, by R.C. Sproul with a forward by Dr. Roger Nicole. We have these available at our Ligonier Ministries. I think they cost $2 or something like, that but in any case, if you write, we’ll be happy to send it. And I do recommend this for people who are trying to wade through the intricacies of this debate. Because, again, as we examine this term inerrancy, and how it has been used in church history, it’s a long way from this negative term that I had heard thrown around loosely and sardonically when I was in Seminary, but I’ll get to that in a moment. Let’s look, then, at these three concepts of inspiration, infallibility, and inerrancy. As I mentioned earlier in our session, when Paul says in second Timothy that all of the Scripture is inspired of God, that’s the English translation. I mentioned that the word he used there should be translated, expiration, rather than inspiration, because it is calling attention to the origin of the content of Scripture, not to the means or the method by which God endowed, or governed, or enabled human authors to become the instruments of or the agents of His divine revelation. But that’s what the word inspiration refers to. In theology, the term inspiration does not simply refer to somebody who is extraordinarily gifted or insightful or has a certain engaging charisma. Where we might hear a trumpet player play a triple tongue riff in jazz, and when he’s done we’ll says, “Wow. That was a inspired performance. ” We don’t mean by that that God Almighty enabled him in some supernatural way to play the trumpet. Although we may wonder about that with people like Dizzie Gillispie and so on. But, that was not what is meant by an inspired actor, or inspired football player, or somebody who gives an inspired performance about something. When we’re talking about inspiration in theology, we’re talking about an activity that takes place through divine and supernatural help, or the term that we use is superintendent. By which, the human author is enabled to be a vehicle for God’s Word to be set forth. That’s what we mean by inspiration. Now, in classical Christian theology, the church has not defined in detail exactly how that inspiration takes place, or what we would call the mode of the inspiration. And there is a world of misunderstanding about this. Some people, when they hear that word, inspiration, or verbal inspiration of the Bible, what immediately comes into their mind is the idea that the human authors, as they set about the task of writing the Gospel of Luke or of John or whatever, that they were virtual automatons. That their pen was seized supernaturally by the Holy Ghost in such a way as to bypass, to quench, to squelch altogether any of the humanity of that writer. So that his pen worked as a Ouija board, or as what we would call a kind of automatic writing, or where the humanity of the human author was so emptied, in this process, that the author became virtually a machine in the hands of God. Such a view of inspiration is called, therefore, a mechanical view of inspiration, meaning that the human author is reduced to the status of a machine. Now, I don’t know how many times I’ve heard people say to me, “I don’t believe in verbal inspiration, the orthodox view, because I don’t believe that God reduced people to puppets and made them machines.” And sometimes I get impatient, and I want to say. “Have you read anything in the history of Christian literature on this point, because for centuries those Christian theologians who have articulated the view of verbal inspiration have been super careful to point out that what they certainly did not mean by Divine superintendence was mechanical inspiration.” Another theory that is rejected in orthodoxy with respect to verbal inspiration is what is called the dictation theory. Again, if you hear the term inspiration maybe you’re thinking that what inspiration means or what it suggests to you is that while Luke was at his desk writing on the parchment, preparing the scroll of his book, God was dictating what he was to write down in his ear, just as I might pick up the telephone and call into the office, to my secretary, and say, “Can I ask you to take this down and send out this letter?” And I tell her what to write, word for word, and so, she types it up and sends it over my signature and her initials. She actually is the writer, but she’s not really the author because all she is doing is recording what I have dictated. They’re my words in her pen. Now, when I say orthodoxy does not subscribe to this notion of... of inspiration, dictation. out this letter?” And I t The Holy Spirit dictating. So there’s the word. If anybody wants to lay any blame for a dictation theory of inspiration, here’s historical evidence that someone somehow in a very important position in the Roman Catholic Church council of the highest magnitude uses the term. However, though the term dictating is used at Trent, the concept, the concept of God whispering words to a human writer or saying them aloud is not conveyed by that concept, even at Trent. And the Church has stopped short of defining precisely the mode of inspiration. Now, the second concept, infallibility, is one that has intrigued me considerably. Again, I go back to my... to my Seminary days when there was such a negative hostile reaction to the word inerrancy, but there wasn’t that same sort of violent vehement protest against the word infallibility. Now they consciously were trying to write a weaker statement, but in terms of the meaning of the words, ladies and gentlemen, they strengthened the statement. Because the term infallible means unable to fail, incapable of making a mistake, whereas the term inerrancy simply says that mistake is not made. Now, is it possible for human beings without the help of divine superintendence, without the assistance of God the Holy Spirit, to do anything inerrantly? Let me say it again, “Is it possible for a human being without any special help from God to do anything inerrantly?” I would be deceitful to take a point off. It wouldn’t be just. But he makes a hundred. He’s inerrant. But I know he’s not infallible. And that his inerrancy is temporary. I mean I could write an inerrancy, an inerrant grocery list. If you want to know what three items we need to buy at the store, and say, “We need bread; we need catsup; and we need salt. And, given the vast scope of Scripture if human beings were left to themselves without any special assistance from God, I would be the last person in the world to assume that what we would have would be an inerrant work. But what I’m saying is, “Inerrancy is not as strong as infallibility.” To be inerrant simply means one does not err. To be infallible means one cannot err. And the executive council debated the question, “How shall we define this organization? Should we define ourselves as theologians who are concerned to propagate the concept of inerrancy?” And I remember saying at that time that I think inerrancy is a bad word strategically. That the Word of God is true and trustworthy, that’s what we’re concerned about. Well, how could it be true and trustworthy if it weren’t inerrant? And if it has errors, it’s not altogether true, and if it has errors, it’s not altogether trustworthy. But I would say, I think we need a word that’s more neutral. I said it’s a shibboleth. J. ’” And people who weren’t Jewish couldn’t say “shibboleth.” They’d stutter all over that word. And so only a true Jew could utter it. I remember when I lived in Holland that the... the Dutch had the same kind of a shibboleth test during World War II, for... to keep the Germans from sneaking in places they weren’t supposed to be. They had a little seacoast town called Schaveningen. ” Which is sheer dishonesty. It happens every day, I’m sad to say, in the world of theology. But, he said, “People really choke on inerrancy.” He said, “They’re not going to say they believe inerrancy unless they really believe it. Why give them an easy way to cheat? Because every theologian knows what is meant by inerrancy and what isn’t meant by inerrancy, and it’s a perfectly meaningful and significant word, and it’s a good word historically, let’s stick with it.” And I was persuaded by that. I said, good for you. Here I was ready to And they’re going to say you’re not academic, you’re not intelligent, you’re not scholarly if you embrace a term like that. And if you’re not secure in your scholarship or in your intelligence, maybe you might be intimidated to negotiate. I think that’s one of the reasons why people change from inerrancy to infallible. The concept of infallibility is associated historically with what, with the institution of the Roman Catholic Church. Infallibility of the Church, infallibility of the Papacy, defined in 1870 by Pius the ninth, but a doctrine, which has been defended, for example, by Jesuit theologians. And whatever else you think about Jesuit theologians and Roman Catholic theologians, not too often that somebody says, “They’re stupid. Finally, before I finish this little time of definition, the other problem with inerrancy is inerrancy must be carefully defined. To mean... what it does not mean is that it does not mean that there aren’t grammatical crudities to be found in the Bible. Or, does it mean, that the Bible speaks with absolute scientific precision. Somebody who has objected to inerrancy because Jesus said that if you have faith as a grain of mustard, as like a mustard seed, you will be able to say to this mountain, and so on, say that the mustard seed is the smallest seed of all. And people say, well wait. We have found smaller seeds than the mustard seed. That’s the Biblical concept of truth. And all that orthodoxy has insisted is that the Bible, on every page and with every word, is utterly and completely consistent with the Bible’s own definition of truth. The Bible’s inspired, it’s infallible. Well, let me back up, it’s inspired; therefore, it’s infallible. And, it’s infallible; therefore, it is inerrant."

prompt: Introduce the ”financial markets and institutions“ by Frederic S. Mishkin
answer:
Financial markets are places where people and institutions trade financial assets. Financial assets include stocks, bonds, derivatives and currencies. Financial markets can be classified into two main categories: capital markets and money markets. Capital markets are markets for long-term raising of capital, whereas money markets are for short-term borrowing of money. The former are also referred to as equity markets and the latter as debt markets.

The two most important financial markets in the world are the stock market (also called the equity market) and the bond market. The stock market refers to a collection of stock exchanges around the world where buyers and sellers exchange ownership of stock in publicly traded companies. The bond market refers to the market for lending money to governments, corporations and other entities. Bonds are considered to be loans to these entities and are traded at bond markets.

In addition to these two markets, there are a number of other markets that facilitate trading in financial assets. The derivatives market is one such market where financial contracts derived from other assets are traded. These contracts are often used for hedging or trading purposes. The foreign exchange market or forex market is another important financial market where currencies are traded.

prompt: when are hops added to the brewing process?
answer: hops are typically added to the brewing process late in the boil.  Hops impart bitterness and aroma to the finished beer.  The longer the hops remain in the boil, the more bitterness and aroma they will add.  Hops are added in the last 45 minutes of the boil to add bitterness and the last 5 minutes to add aroma.

So theoretically, with a 50% margin for error, the LTM 11200-9.1 could lift Mount Everest, assuming a "ground level" (i.e. base) position. However, it is important to note that the LTM 11200-9.1 is a crane, and not a forklift. While it could theoretically be used to pick up Mount Everest and place it on another surface, it could not climb the mountain itself.

prompt: what are five important topics for game design
answer:
1. Gameplay First: This is the philosophy that the designer should first focus on creating a fun and engaging game experience, and then add in the "meat" such as story, characters, and content. This is the opposite of an "Art First" design philosophy, where the design is driven by the world building and content.
2. Game Feel: This is the sensation that the player gets when interacting with the game world. This can be controlled by how responsive the physics or other in-game systems are, as well as the audio design of the game. Good game feel can add to the immersion of the player into the experience.
3. Flow: This refers to the sense of progress and accomplishment the player gets as they play through the game. A good game has a smooth and uninterrupted flow from one challenge or activity to another.
4. Metagame: This refers to aspects of the game that occur outside the actual gameplay. Examples of this would be the player's interaction with the game's community and economy, as well as their unlocking of achievements. Metagame features can enhance or detract from the player's experience.
5. Pacing: This refers to how fast or slow the gameplay is. A slow or methodical gameplay can be relaxing or stress relieving, while a fast pace can be exciting or adrenaline inducing. Good pacing creates variety in the player's experience as the game progresses.

prompt: 2 / 2can you list in bullet points for the role of digital health in preventing the diseases
answer:
1. Digital health can be used to monitor patients remotely and detect disease earlier, e.g. using AI to analyse patient data and detect disease or changes in disease progression.
2. Digital health can be used to educate patients on disease prevention and self-care, e.g. providing patient education materials, videos and apps.
3. Digital health can be used to incentivise patients to take prescribed preventative actions, e.g. by providing them with digital badges or other rewards for taking certain actions.
4. Digital health can be used to motivate patients to take part in clinical trials, e.g. by providing patients with digital games or other digital tools to engage with.
5. Digital health can be used to connect patients with each other or with healthcare providers, e.g. through patient portals or forums, to provide social support for patients.
6. Digital health can be used to provide remote patient monitoring, e.g. using devices such as wearables or connected scales to collect patient data.
7. Digital health can be used to integrate and analyse large datasets to conduct research on disease prevention, e.g. to analyse data from electronic health records or from mobile health apps.

Neither town has a professional sports team, but Flagstaff has a minor league baseball team and Kaneohe has a rugby team.  Both towns have a diverse and delicious selection of local restaurants, and are known for their craft beer.  Flagstaff has a strong music and arts culture, while Kaneohe has a vibrant surf culture.  Both towns are known for being welcoming to newcomers.

prompt: ideas for building a waitlist for a new product or service
answer:
Generally, when launching a new product or service, you will not be able to meet the demand for users right away. One way to address this is by building a waitlist which allows people interested in using your product or service to sign up to be notified when it is available.

There are several ways to build a waitlist. One approach is to simply use a spreadsheet that people can sign up for manually. However, this can be time-consuming to maintain and difficult to scale. If you are expecting a lot of demand, you may want to consider using a platform that makes it easy to add new users and manage the waitlist automatically. Some services that offer this functionality include Launchrock, Mailchimp, and Intercom Waitlist.

Additionally, it's important to communicate what waiting in the waitlist means. For example, you may offer users priority access to the product, or notify them first when the product is ready. Finally, it's important to track user engagement and remove inactive users to keep the list manageable.

Are you feeling the sensation in your body? Are you feeling your heart beat? Breathing in that sensation, breathe out and send love to yourself.

prompt: Who will be the president of South Korea in 2023?
answer:
At the 2022 presidential election, Moon Jae-in will seek a second term as President of South Korea. Moon will run as the candidate of the opposition Minjoo Party of Korea. If reelected, he will be the second incumbent South Korean president to serve a full five-year term since the country's transition to a democracy in 1987.

Moon will face a conservative candidate backed by his own party's main rival, the Liberty Korea Party. He will also face an independent candidate supported by the opposition Bareun Party. In the 2017 election, Moon defeated then-President Park Geun-hye's conservative candidate, the former Governor of South Chungcheong Province Hong Joon-pyo, by a wide margin. Moon's approval ratings peaked at 88% immediately after his inauguration, but have since declined, in part due to his administration's perceived failure to address high youth unemployment. Moon is the first South Korean president to have earned a doctorate degree, and is often described as an "outsider" who has not benefited from the "old Boy's network".

prompt:
Write an article about the site's backlink and its importance"Use the following keywords in the article Questions Others Asked
What is a backlink example?
What are SEO backlinks?
Do backlinks help SEO?
How do I get backlinks?"
answer:
A backlink, or inbound link, is when an external website links to your website. Search engines view these backlinks as votes of confidence for your content and your website. This is why backlinks are important for SEO. When other websites link to you, it passes some of their authority to your website. It also helps your content be discovered by search engines and potential customers. When search engines crawl your website, they look at the number and quality of backlinks to your website. The more high-quality backlinks you have, the higher you will rank in search results.

Examples of backlinks include when another website links to your blog post, or when another website mentions your brand name (such as Twitter handle) in their content. Backlinks can come from other websites, blogs, social media posts, or even comments on other websites or blogs.

prompt: In order to launch a token for a Defi project, I want to sell some tokens privately to early investors and then add it to a launchpad. let me know what can I do with my smart contract? Should I create a presale contract separate from main contract?
answer:
In order to launch a token for a DeFi project, you can sell some tokens privately to early investors and then add it to a launchpad.

By default, every Ethereum smart contract has 2 functions: "function", which can be executed by anyone, and "account", which can be used only by the owner of the address.

I recommend you to create a contract with 2 functions: function to create tokens and function to transfer tokens. In the first function, create 200 tokens and transfer them to the owner address. In the second function, create 100 tokens and transfer them to the early investors.

There is no need to create a separate presale contract because the smart contract is run once.

prompt: what is the recommended pattern for creating games in godot
answer:
There is no single right way to create a game in Godot, but there are some common patterns and practices. Here are some tips on how to structure a game project in Godot:

Use a project setup that is appropriate for the size of your project. For example, you may want to use a monolitic project if the game is small and simple, but a modular project if the game is large and complex.

Create a root scene that contains all the main elements of your game. This scene will be the root of your scene graph, and will be automatically loaded when the game starts.

Create other scenes as needed. These scenes should be children of the root scene.

Create a main_loop() function that is a child of the root scene, and is responsible for managing the game loop. This function should be called from the init() function of the root scene.

Create a Game class that defines some high-level gameplay logic and state. This class should be a child of the root scene, and should have a method called update() that is called by the main_loop() function.

Create different Components that encapsulate the game logic for specific game elements, such as sprites, scenes, and behaviors. These Components should be children of the Game class.

Implement a render() method in each Component that is responsible for drawing its game element(s) to the screen.

Implement input callbacks for each Component that are responsible for handling input events for the game element(s) encapsulated by the Component.

Implement behavior callbacks for each Component that are responsible for handling game logic for the game element(s) encapsulated by the Component.

prompt: i'm working on a spatial analysis project and am looking for questions I can answer with it related housing and crime analysis, do you have suggestions?
answer:
Housing and crime are two topics that are often studied with spatial analysis. 

One way to do crime analysis is to look at where crimes happen, and identify any spatial patterns.  You might find that crimes tend to cluster in certain areas, or that certain types of crimes are concentrated in certain areas.  You could also analyze the relationship between crime and other factors, such as weather, or the social and economic conditions of the area. 

For housing analysis, you could look at where people are choosing to live, and identify any spatial patterns.  You might find that people are concentrated in certain areas, or that certain types of people are concentrated in certain areas.  You could also analyze the relationship between housing and other factors, such as land values, access to amenities, or the social and economic conditions of the area.

Both crime and housing are complex topics that can be analyzed with spatial analysis, and there are many interesting questions that you could answer.

prompt: The sum of the distances the sun travels around the Earth during a solar eclipse is 1059 kilometres. Write a formula that finds the distance between the sun and Earth. How many years will the eclipse last?
answer: The Earth orbits the sun at an average distance of 150 million kilometres. During a solar eclipse, the sun appears to pass through the moon's shadow. The total duration of a solar eclipse is typically a few hours. The duration of totality - when the sun is completely obscured - is typically less than one minute. The distance between the Earth and the moon is about 384,000 kilometres. Therefore, the sun appears to move a distance of about 1059 kilometres across the sky during a total solar eclipse. The next total solar eclipse will take place on 21 August 2017 and will be visible in parts of the USA. The eclipse will last for up to 7.5 minutes.

Krishnamurti is not so well known in the West as he was in the past, and he is not as well known in the East as he was in the past. But his teachings are really revolutionary, and his ideas are profound. If you have read some of his books, for example, "On Freedom", you would have got an idea of what he is talking about.

prompt: Need 300 words on the importance to documenting history in relation to the future
answer: Human beings have a unique ability to document and store information about the past. This ability is crucial for understanding the past and learning from it. When it comes to understanding the present and planning for the future, historical information becomes even more valuable. For example, the weather today will be quite different from the weather yesterday because the sun is moving across the sky and the earth is rotating. This is a simple example of how the present is shaped by the past. If we didn’t have any historical information about past weather and sun positions, it would be very difficult to accurately predict the weather for the coming days. Similarly, if we didn’t have any historical information about past societies, it would be very difficult to understand how our current society came to be, and what the future of our society might be. By documenting and storing historical information, we are preserving our past and using it to make informed decisions about our present and future.

prompt: Why did the building of a pipeline have to be voted on by the government(USA)? Doesn't this infringe on government interfering with private corporations?
answer:
The Keystone Pipeline was a proposed 1,200-mile (1,900 km) long, 36-inch-diameter (91 cm) pipeline that would have carried 830,000 barrels per day (132,000 m3/d) of crude oil from western Canada to refineries in the United States. It was proposed by TransCanada, a Canadian energy company. The project was first proposed in 2005.

The pipeline would have crossed the border at Morgan, Montana, and terminated at the oil hub in Patoka, Illinois. From there, the oil would have been transported by other pipelines to refineries on the Gulf Coast. The pipeline was to be constructed in the United States, but owned and operated by a Canadian company. 

In 2015, the Obama administration denied a permit for the pipeline's construction, citing environmental concerns. President Trump issued a presidential permit for the pipeline in 2017. In 2019, a federal judge ordered a halt to construction of the pipeline pending further environmental review. The Trump administration appealed the decision.

prompt:
Simplify "Most of the basic functions of current virtualization software are inherited from this early VM OS. The virtualization software is now represented with the term hypervisor. Hardware virtualization is used to share the resources of the cloud providers effectively with the customers by generating an illusion of dedicated computing, storage, and networking on a computing infrastructure.

The concept of virtualization is physically implemented using the hypervisor modules, and the operation and processing of hypervisors are materialized by the OSS. In other words, hypervisor modules are installed on top of OSS, which act as an interface between hardware units and hypervisor packages."
answer:
Virtualization is a technique for creating a virtual (rather than actual) version of something, such as a hardware platform, operating system (OS), or network resources. In modern computing, virtualization is commonly implemented using software that creates a virtual version of the underlying hardware (e.g., a virtual machine (VM) monitor). The software provides resources to the virtual machine (VM) that allow the VM to run as if it were running on the actual hardware, while the VM actually runs on the host machine. This allows multiple virtual machines to run simultaneously on the same physical hardware, each unaware of the existence of the others. This is called virtual machine virtualization, and is the dominant use of the term.

A cloud is a pool of hardware, software, and services that can be rapidly provisioned and released with minimal management effort or service provider interaction. The cloud model is based on abstraction, where the details of the hardware and software below the cloud layer are hidden by a higher-level interface. This enables the rapid scaling of resources up or down to match demand. Virtualization is one enabling technology for cloud computing, as it allows multiple independent VMs to run on the same physical hardware.

Most of the basic functions of current virtualization software are inherited from this early VM OS. The virtualization software is now represented with the term hypervisor. Hardware virtualization is used to share the resources of the cloud providers effectively with the customers by generating an illusion of dedicated computing, storage, and networking on a computing infrastructure.

The concept of virtualization is physically implemented using the hypervisor modules, and the operation and processing of hypervisors are materialized by the OSS. In other words, hypervisor modules are installed on top of OSS, which act as an interface between hardware units and hypervisor packages.

prompt: what are african governments doing to improve air traffic connectivity
answer:
As connectivity in Africa increases through investments in mobile networks and other technologies, governments across the continent are also beginning to invest in air traffic control (ATC) technologies, to improve connectivity between airports.

The African Union Commission (AUC) and the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) are working together to help governments to improve air traffic connectivity across the continent.

In 2018, ICAO and the AUC signed a Memorandum of Understanding to cooperate in the field of ATC. The AUC and ICAO also work together through the AUC’s Air Transport Facilitation and Harmonisation Implementation Task Force (ATFHITF).

ICAO provides technical assistance and capacity building to member states to help them to establish or strengthen their ATC infrastructure.

ICAO also provides guidance on implementing key ATC technologies, including satellite-based navigation and communications, digital datalink and performance-based navigation.

In 2019, ICAO launched a three-year project to support the AU’s Agenda 2063, which aims to transform the continent into a “continent of prosperity and opportunity” by 2063.

Through the project, ICAO and the AUC will work together to help African states to improve their ATC systems and modernize their air navigation infrastructure.

prompt: what are the important points for brand promotion and brand marketing
answer:
1. Create a brand strategy: The first step in any branding or marketing process is to create a strategy. This will provide you with a roadmap for your brand identity, and act as a guide for all other decisions that you will make.
2. Create a brand personality: Once you have developed your brand strategy, you can start to think about the personality and values that you want your brand to reflect. This will help you to create a consistent and authentic voice across all of your communications.
3. Define your target audience: Once you have established your brand personality, you can start to think about who you are communicating with. This will help you to tailor your messages, ensuring that they resonate with your audience.
4. Create your brand identity: Once you have defined your brand personality and target audience, you can start to think about how you are going to communicate your brand to the world. This will involve the creation of your logo, colour palette, imagery, and any other visual elements that will be used as part of your overall brand identity.
5. Build your brand awareness: Once you have defined your brand identity, the next step is to start promoting your brand. This can involve online activity such as social media, or offline techniques such as PR and events. The goal of this stage is to increase awareness of your brand and the values and personality that it stands for.
6. Increase customer engagement: Once customers are aware of your brand, the next step is to encourage them to engage with it. This can be achieved through a variety of techniques, such as providing useful and relevant content, and providing a superior customer experience. The goal of this stage is to turn customers into advocates of your brand.

- Live Sports - There is a lot of interest in live sporting events, but there are few companies that are able to broadcast these for free in a quality stream. This leaves viewers with few options to find local content that is relevant to them.

prompt: in billiards what happens if on the break every strip ball is pocketed?
answer:
In billiards, a "stripe run" is a sequence of shots in which all of the object balls are either struck with a stripe-patterned cue ball or result in the cue ball becoming contact with a stripe-patterned object ball. The stripes are white, and the spots are colored. 

In a break, the first shot of a game of billiards, a stripe run is called a "solid break". If one or more of the object balls are pocketed on the break, it is called a "foul break". If the breaker pockets all of the object balls on the break, it is called a "perfect break". A "scratch" is an imperfect break, where at least one of the object balls is not pocketed, or the breaker commits a foul.

If none of the object balls are pocketed on the break, it is called a "miss". A "partial" or "weak" miss is one in which one or more of the object balls is close to a pocket, but not pocketed. A "strong" miss is one in which none of the object balls are close to a pocket.

If the breaker commits a foul on the break, they must take the cue ball in hand behind the headstring, and the incoming player (the opponent of the breaker) has a number of options:

If the breaker had committed a "serious" foul (such as jumping ship, hitting an object ball more than once, or striking a cushion with the cue ball), then the incoming player has the option of either:
  * shooting, and their first shot is called a "push".
  * stating "foul", and the incoming player's first shot is also a foul, but they are awarded possession of the table.

If the breaker had committed a "minor" foul (such as striking a ball with the cue ball or the rack), then the incoming player's first shot is also a foul, but they are not awarded the table.

If the breaker had committed a "wild" foul (such as striking the cue ball with an object ball, or contacting the cue ball with anything other than the tip of their cue), then the incoming player's first shot is a foul, but they are awarded the table, and the breaker loses their turn and all remaining turns at the table.

prompt: #2. To increase the energy efficiency of windows, additional glass pane is added. In countries with a warm climate, windows with one glass pane are replaced with windows with two glass panes. Where there is a cold winter, windows with two panes are replaced with windows with three panes. Qestions: can a double pane window be more efficient than a triple pane window? Can a single pane window be more efficient than a double pane window? If yes, what is needed for this? Support your answer with appropriate calculations.
answer: A double pane window can be more efficient than a triple pane window. However, a single pane window can never be more efficient than a double pane window. This is because the energy required to heat the inside of a window in a cold climate is proportional to the temperature difference between the inside and outside of the window. In other words, for a given window, the energy needed to heat the inside of the window increases as the temperature difference between the inside and outside of the window decreases. Therefore, for a window in a cold climate, the larger the difference between the inside and outside temperature of the window, the more efficient the window is. In order to achieve a larger temperature difference, you need to have a larger pane of glass. Therefore, a double pane window will always be more efficient than a single pane window in a cold climate.

prompt: Make a slide to introduce Cantonese
answer:
Cantonese is a variety of Chinese spoken across southeastern China, in the territory of Hong Kong and Macau, and by the Chinese diaspora in Southeast Asia and elsewhere. It is the de facto official language of Hong Kong and the language of instruction in schools in the territory.

Although the Chinese government officially recognizes four "functional" regional languages, namely Mandarin, Wu, Yue, and Min, Cantonese is not officially designated as such, and as a result, is not used in some governmental and official contexts, such as in the media, in the courts, or in some official publications.

prompt: Rewrite the given introductory paragraph so that it starts with a pertinent anecdote. Also rewrite the thesis so that it is succinct and concise:    "Many types of black people have different cultural backgrounds and experiences. For example, African and African American cultures share a common ancestry and history of struggles but have distinct cultural identities. While both groups are considered Black, they have different experiences, records, and cultural practices. As Saint Augustine said, “The world is a book, and those who do not travel read only a page.” This quote emphasizes the importance of exploring other cultures to understand their experiences better. As I have gotten older, I have come to understand the similarities and differences between these two individuals."
answer: Many types of black people have different cultural backgrounds and experiences. For example, African and African American cultures share a common ancestry and history of struggles but have distinct cultural identities. While both groups are considered Black, they have different experiences, records, and cultural practices. As Saint Augustine said, “The world is a book, and those who do not travel read only a page.” This quote emphasizes the importance of exploring other cultures to understand their experiences better. As I have gotten older, I have come to understand the similarities and differences between these two individuals. While they both share a common ancestry, their experiences have been shaped by economic and social factors. For example, African Americans often faced discrimination and had fewer economic opportunities. This led to their communities facing structural inequalities and poverty. While African cultures did not face the same level of discrimination, they were exploited and colonized by European powers, which impacted their social and economic development. Despite these differences, both groups share a common African ancestry and have similar musical, culinary, and religious practices. Understanding their differences and commonalities is important to develop a deeper understanding of how history and culture shape our identities.

prompt: explain TypeScript and Duck Typing
answer: TypeScript is a typed superset of JavaScript.  One of the features of TypeScript is that it enforces type safety.  TypeScript also allows for a concept called "duck typing".  Duck Typing is the ability to cast one object to another object, even if the two objects do not have the same type.  For example, in JavaScript you could cast a number to a string.  TypeScript allows you to cast a number to a string, so long as the number can represent a valid string.  In TypeScript, the number "123" can be cast to a string because the number 123 can be represented as the string "123".  However, in TypeScript you cannot cast a number to an object because the number "123" cannot be represented as the string "123".  The string "123" only has 3 characters, and an object can have any number of characters.  So, in summary, TypeScript allows for duck typing, but only if the object being cast has a type that can be represented by the value being cast.

prompt: how are carbon fibers used in buildings
answer: Carbon fibers are used in the construction of buildings for a variety of reasons. They are strong yet lightweight, able to withstand high temperatures, and resistant to corrosion. Their high stiffness-to-weight ratio makes them ideal for use in civil engineering applications, such as in the construction of suspension bridges. The distinctive blue-coloured carbon fibers are used to strengthen polymers such as plastics and resins, which in turn are used for insulation and to make wind turbine blades.

prompt:
Please summarise in point form "Challenges for
African Agriculture" by Jean-Claude Devèze
answer:
1. Food security: to achieve food security, Africa must double its agricultural production by 2050. This requires addressing challenges such as limited access to land, labor and inputs, high production costs, inadequate infrastructure and markets, and climate change.
2. Agricultural productivity: Africa must increase agricultural productivity in order to double production by 2050. This can be achieved by improving soil fertility, crop varieties, irrigation, agricultural extension services, market infrastructure, and access to finance.
3. Climate change: Africa's agriculture is particularly vulnerable to climate change, with potential impacts including decreased crop yields, droughts, soil degradation, and the spread of pests and diseases. Adaptation measures include diversified farming systems, improved seed varieties, greater use of water harvesting and storage, and the promotion of tree planting.
4. Land tenure: Secure land tenure is a prerequisite for investment in agriculture, particularly for smallholder farmers. In Africa, laws that give recognition to the rights of women to own and control land are particularly lacking.
5. Financing: Africa's agriculture sector is underfunded, with financing needs estimated at $13 billion to $21 billion per year. This is due to a range of constraints, including insufficient financial infrastructure, poor access to markets, and low incomes.
6. Youth engagement: The agriculture sector offers many opportunities for young people, including employment, self-employment, and entrepreneurship. However, many young people in Africa are disengaged from agriculture, due to a lack of interest, inadequate education and training, and limited access to financing and markets.
7. Technology adoption: Agricultural technologies such as improved seeds, fertilizers, and irrigation could significantly increase yields and incomes, but are underutilized in Africa. This is due to lack of awareness, limited availability, high costs, and poor infrastructure.

prompt: Why does it feel like less effort to watch 3 - hour long TV episodes back to back than a film?

prompt: Explain sarcoidosis to me like I’m a five year old
answer:
Sarcoidosis is an immune system disease. When you have sarcoidosis, your immune system makes clumps of cells called granulomas that form in different parts of your body. These clumps can lead to inflammation and damage to your organs.

Sarcoidosis can affect any part of the body. Your organs most commonly affected are your lungs, your eyes, and your skin.

Nobody knows what causes sarcoidosis. It most commonly affects young adults age 20 to 40. But you can get it at any age. It affects women more often than men.

If you have sarcoidosis, your doctor may give you a treatment called steroids to help control your symptoms. If your symptoms don’t go away after taking steroids, your doctor might also give you a treatment called an immunosuppressant, which can help prevent your immune system from attacking your organs.

You may also need to have some tests to check how sarcoidosis is affecting your organs. One common test is a chest X-ray. If your doctor thinks your sarcoidosis may be affecting your heart or brain, you might have an MRI or a CT scan to check for damage.

There’s no known cure for sarcoidosis. But many people who have it lead healthy, active lives.

prompt: Is it rational to believe things for which there is no objective evidence?
answer: It is not rational to believe things for which there is no objective evidence.  The burden of proof rests on the claimant to demonstrate that their belief is rational.  Objective evidence is evidence that is observable or measurable by a third party without bias.  Subjective evidence is evidence that is based on the claimant's own perceptions or opinions.  Claiming that one has a personal relationship with God is a subjective belief, as is the belief that aliens have visited Earth or that magic is real.  These types of claims have no objective evidence to support them and therefore it is not rational to believe them.

prompt:
A man has a rather old car being worth $2000.
He saw a secondhand car being worth $8000. He wants to keep his old car until he can buy the secondhand one.
He thinks he can save $1000 each month but the prices of his old
car and of the new one decrease of 1.5 percent per month.
Furthermore this percent of loss increases of `0.5` percent
Our man finds it difficult to make all these calculations.
Can you help him?
How many months will it take him to save up enough money to buy the car he wants,
and how much money will he have left over?
answer:
Let's call the price of the old car $x, the price of the new car $y, the monthly decrease in the price of the old car $u, and the increase in the price of the new car $v. The man can save $1000 per month. Each month he will have $1000 less than before, as the price of the car he owns decreases by $u, and the price of the car he wants to buy increases by $v.

We can use the formula for the compound growth rate to find the number of months it will take him to save up $1000. This is: $1000 / (r - u) = 1000 / (0.015 - 0.01) = 1000 / 0.005 = 200 months, or 16.67 years. After 16.67 years, the price of the old car will have decreased by 1000 times 16.67, or 166.7, times the monthly decrease, u, or 166.7u. So after 16.67 years, the price of the old car will be $2000 * 166.7u, or $3336.7. The price of the new car will have increased by 1000 times 16.67, or 166.7v, or 166.7v times the increase per month, v, or 166.7v * 0.015, or $259.30. So the total cost of the new car will be $8000 + $259.30 = $8259.30. After 16.67 years, the man will have saved $1000 * 16.67, or $16670. So he will have $8259.30 - $16670 = -$7983.30.

prompt: 7 / 7Write a detailed patent writing for an innovative and novel way of issuing community tax certificates and other relevant permits and clearances as a digital certificates,  that is non-obvious using verifiable credentials, digital wallet on a blockchain as payment provision, and machine learning. Include claims on detailed processes involved, system architecture and algorithms
answer:
Community Tax Certificate (CTC) is a government issued document that is required to be obtained by every individual and business entity residing in a particular geographical area. The certificate is issued by the local governing body and contains details of the entity and its address. The certificate has to be renewed annually. Currently, the process of acquiring the CTC is manual and involves visiting the government office, filling up multiple forms, submitting supporting documents, and paying fees. The process is error prone and time consuming.

There is a need for an innovative solution that can automate the process of issuance of CTC and all other permits and clearances. The solution should be secure, scalable, and be accessible to a large number of people. The core requirements of the solution are:

1. It should be possible to issue a digital CTC that can be verified using verifiable credentials.
2. Payment for the CTC should be facilitated using a blockchain based digital wallet.
3. The system should use machine learning algorithms to detect fraudulent and incorrect information.
4. The system should be secure, scalable, and fast.

The proposed solution leverages blockchain technology to enable issuance of digital CTCs. The blockchain serves as a distributed ledger that maintains the following information about a particular entity:
1. Name of the entity
2. Address of the entity
3. Date of issuance
4. Expiry date
5. Digital CTC

The blockchain is programmed to maintain this information in an immutable and tamper-proof manner. The information in the blockchain can be queried by anyone using a read-only permission. However, in order to write to the blockchain, a user has to be authenticated using a verifiable credential. For example, the government can issue digital CTCs only to entities that have submitted their identity proof and address proof.

The blockchain also maintains information about transactions performed between different entities. This information can be leveraged to detect fraudulent and incorrect transactions. For example, if the blockchain maintains information about the CTCs issued to a person, it can be used to detect a scenario where the same person obtains multiple CTCs for the same address.

The solution also leverages digital wallets to facilitate secure and easy payments. The blockchain maintains the digital wallets of different entities and allows them to transfer value between each other. For example, the government can setup a digital wallet and allow citizens to pay for the annual CTC renewal fee using the digital wallet.

The proposed solution leverages the core concepts of blockchain and machine learning to provide a secure, fast, and scalable platform for issuance of digital CTCs and other permits and clearances.

prompt:
Rewrite this text in 500 words: "There’s much that divides us in Northern Ireland though one thing is guaranteed to bring us together: local phrases. Call it slang, call it colloquialisms, we all know only too well how important words are to where we’re from . . . and when it comes to the phrases that make us ‘us,’ we’ve got a lot to say.
While you don’t need advance knowledge of the words to fit in, well, it helps. How else will you know where ‘foundered’ sits on the scale of warm to freezing? Or deciding whether that new car purchase is more ‘clinker’ than ‘beezer’? Or appreciating that ‘grand’ can mean exactly that or anything but?
If the best way to get to know a nation is to understand their language, then surely tourists must be at times confused about what comes out of our mouths. Throughout the island of Ireland, we have utterly brilliant ways to verbally express ourselves.
“I think it’s really important,” says Dr Frank Ferguson, research director for English Language and Literature at Ulster University, about the vitality of slang as part of language.
“I think sometimes we’re not sure even the meaning of slang and the meaning of the vernacular and the colloquial. Especially for Northern Ireland, where language is often so divisive, we forget how a rich and varied it is. And sometimes we find other places in the world that really value the mix of their language.
“Often the things that we associate with slang are actually part of the sort of the languages that make up what we think of as English because we have this wonderful mixture of English, Scots language, and Irish, all bubbling up together and then you have the additions on that, of slang,” he continues.
“Slang as a sort of term that’s used by certain groups to denote certain things through phrases.
“We have an incredible mix and you think how small in many ways Northern Ireland is, that there are marked differences in the language that Belfast uses and the language that’s used up in Derry. There are gradation and the usage of words and phrases that we often take for granted but they’re really quite amazing things.”
“It’s a potentially massive term,” says Gail McConnell, a writer from Belfast on slang which she says transcends distinctions of high and low culture.
“One of the reasons why so many of us love [TV show] Derry Girls so much is because it was a language, phrasing and words and speech, that was so familiar, and took such a delight and pleasure in not just Northern Irish slang but Derry-specific slang, which was a joyous thing to see on a Channel 4 programme.
“But then you’ve got someone like Pulitzer Prize-winning Paul Muldoon, the current Ireland Chair of Poetry, whose poems are peppered with slang terms, through all the decades of his writing; he’s been doing that since the 1970s and 1980s to now.
“It’s a really interesting legacy of this place and the words that make us unique.”
Language has the power to unite: it brings familiarity, a sense of community and a feeling that we’re all in this together. It is our primary tool to communicate and finding those lines of unity is vital to create bonds and friendships.
“It’s one of those things that if we go on holiday and you’re walking down the street, whether it be Spain or wherever, and you hear something from home. It can be something like ‘yer ma’, or ‘yer man’ and that will convey a whole host of knowledge and sense of place that somethings don’t and can’t,” says Dr Ferguson.
“There’s something very unmistakeably ours about words and phrases that we use and there’s nothing more honest at times and nothing more radical.
“Sometimes we might get anxious that we’re using cliches, but we’re actually using things that are very unguarded in our speech.”
Think too of Line of Duty’s Ted Hastings, who may be not living in Northern Ireland but ensures his team appreciate he didn’t come up the Lagan in a bubble.
In popular culture, like Gail, Dr Ferguson also references Lisa McGee’s Derry Girls that unashamedly used phrases and terminology from this place.
“That really said something of the exceptionalism of who we are and what we say.
“Sometimes we’ve been too quick almost to laugh at ourselves for those words, because I think a lot of it is the way society tries to engineer us with an idea of what is proper language, whereas what we say communicates extremely effectively and works better than sometimes the phraseology of standard English.”
But our local phrases are not immune from what goes on here.
“I think it’s unfortunate that it’s been politicised by a face-off between the Irish language and Ulster Scots,” says Gail.
“It’s so frustrating but I think there’s definitely more that we have in common. I think people are often not that sure of the history of slang terms, what the root of it is and where it started.
“And it’s such a source of comedy; I think some of the best of Irish writing, such as James Joyce, used slang. It’s one dimension of what slang can do.”
Dr Ferguson agrees, citing the number of creative writers that Northern Ireland produces who understand the power and ability of language in putting across a moment, or series of moments.
“In many ways, we have a number of registers coming through to us all the time.
“We have that historic mix of English, Scots and Irish, which means then that we can often have two or three words for the same thing.
“We are like the cliche of the Eskimos having so many words for snow; there are, it seems, lots and lots of words out there for ‘potatoes’ that we have.
“Certain areas will have a certain word for certain things and that’s a real strength. I think there’s a variety there and there’s a wonderful history to where those words came from. And even at times, I don’t think we’ve even grasped yet the opportunities that that has for who we are and what we can do and where we can go with that.”
Again, Ulster Scots is mentioned: a language so many of us use without even knowing. Anyone ever had a ‘boak’ after a foodstuff not agreeing with them or done ‘the messages’? My favourite slang word ‘hoke’ has an Ulster Scots origin. It’s fair to say that a discussion on Northern Irish slang cannot be done without looking at Ulster Scots and its continued impact.
“Often there’s not a lot of prestige placed on something like Ulster Scots because there is a perception that it’s bad language, or it doesn’t have a sense of value behind it,” says Dr Ferguson.
“But on one hand, you can trace Ulster Scots back into the courtly language of Scotland and you can also get the sense of the authentic place.
“There are bad Ulster Scots writers, just as there are bad Irish writers or bad English writers, or bad French or bad Spanish writers. But when it’s authentic and done well, it transports you to a real sense of realisation that this is really important and fantastic literature and you’re in the room.
“Whenever anybody questions me about the validity of Ulster Scots, I say go to Seamus Heaney and he talks about reading [poet] Rabbie Burns’ To a Mouse and ‘wee, sleekit, cowrin, tim’rous beastie’ appears in the first line.
“This really electrifies him because the word ‘wee’ appears. It’s the word that he hears at home in his kitchen language as he calls it and it’s also the word that miraculously appears in the world of art and literature and anthologies.
“I think this is when we realised that the very simple words we think we’ve grown up with, we’re maybe a little anxious to use them. When you see the possibilities for those words, there’s something that really brings us home to just how marvellous our language actually is. And actually how it connects us with lots of people in the country at times when there are things that don’t connect us.”
Slang has a special place in painting a vivid image of what it is we’re trying to say. It also gives us an insight into a specific culture and attitude. In Northern Ireland’s case, that we have multiple uses for the word ‘wee.’
“We all know how good a wee cup of tea is, a wee rest or a wee drink or a wee day off. These all have their meanings. It can be cold or be freezing but when it’s Baltic, we know exactly what that means and we know we’re foundered,” says Dr Ferguson.
“One of our great words, and I think there’s a difference between the town and city where it’s ‘scunnered’ or ‘scundered’. You can be annoyed and you can be frustrated, but nothing hits home [than] the sense of ‘I am totally scunnered’ or ‘I am totally scundered’ about something. These are things that we should protect.”
Language too is continuously developing. There are times too when a slang word enters the Oxford English Dictionary (OED) and becomes almost standardised, says Gail.
“Yesterday’s slang term is today or the future’s commonly understood term for something,” she explains.
“I guess that’s how language changes and evolves, through its users. You’re getting a people’s history of language use when you think about slang terms. All language passes through users.
“Every year I’m always interested to see what makes it into the OED — it tells you a lot about the way we speak now and how the dictionary has to keep up with the language that people are using.
“In 2022, ‘a chara’ entered the OED. So did ‘fluthered’, first used by James Joyce in 1927, ‘gaslighter’ and ‘vaxxed’. It’s great to see Irish English there and words that reflect what we’re living through.”
Similarly, Dr Ferguson says the ‘beauty’ of slang is that it’s often at the cutting edge of where words enter into common parlance.
“It often comes from young people so that there is a sense that if somebody like me is using the word, it has long lost its kind of cachet,” he laughs.
“But there’s a there’s a real sense that this is how words get born and taken into language. They’re used in some circles and in some groups.
“We all talk about going to uni now and in a sense, this is Australian dialect that we’ve picked up when Neighbours came along in the 1980s. Suddenly, ‘uni’ seems one of the obvious words to use because it’s been floating through media, but it’s loaded into everyday speech.
“Language is always a kind of magpie; it always throws up things for us to use that we’re not expected to use. Even terms that maybe in the past would have had specific meanings for specific groups, suddenly, this becomes widespread.”
The phrases we barely think about, so bound are they to our identity, are not just ours, however, they’re widely available for visitors to enjoy — on a sock or enamel mug, among other things.
Linzi Rooney is the owner of Born and Bred, a shop celebrating homeware and apparel with a decidedly local twist.
“I think it’s actually gotten more popular,” she says of the slang-adorned items.
“There’s more of a pride and a confidence that has built up from locals because of who we are and where we come from.
“I think that confidence has grown given the number of tourists who are coming into the city. They talk about how friendly we are, they talk about our hospitality and are genuinely interested in the history of the north of Ireland. I think then that our confidence has grown which makes us take a bit more pride in our kind of phrases.”
She launched the business in 2014 and her ethos remains changing the often negative attitudes about Northern Ireland, creating a culture where we’re proud of the places we call home.
From ‘up to high doh’ coasters to ‘a wee bag’ tote, Born and Bred is proudly Northern Irish and equally proud of our famous sayings.
“I knew locals would love it and if you see the amount of actual tourists we have coming into the store in Belfast — 27% of our tourism comes from Scotland and England,” explains Linzi.
“With the Americans coming over and they ask, ‘What’s “awk hiya love?”’ – which we have on our socks and mugs – once you explain it to them, they then love it and they buy it. So they’re running around America with a pair of ‘awk hiya love’ socks on with people asking, ‘What’s awk?’
“It creates engagement in the shop and it’s probably why the shop is doing so well as it’s creating that kind of dialogue with tourists in the shop as opposed to going in, buying something and leaving.
“It opens conversations which is brilliant.”
Top of the festive socks for 2022 was a pair with ‘alright big lad’ and customers still love ‘Ulster says yeooo!’ and ‘ats us nai’.
“Having tourists back last year and also cruise ships was definitely a real confidence boost for the shop,” continues Linzi.
“For the last two years before that, in and around lockdowns, you were relying on local trade which was amazing.
There’s no greater feeling than somebody coming from Spain, China, Italy, America, Canada, and really loving something with a local sign on it.”
How a brand markets items with such a local angle is important, she says.
“I was always very conscious that it’s how you incorporate this kind of slang with your brand, and create a brand that people want to invest in and it’s a lifestyle brand. When you do that and add a bit of Northern Irish tongue in cheek, it’s quite popular.
“It may not want to be a mug you’d have in your house but when you add the pink and enamel and people will take pictures of it up the Mournes or are wearing their ‘alright’ sock in a style that’s trendy and you can see yourself wearing it. If you’re able to tie those two together then you’ve got a good product. It’s not just your fridge magnet with a leprechaun on it.”
Many households live with multiple words of various things, giving a flavour of the melting point of cultures and nationalities for whom Northern Ireland is home.
“I’m married to an American so occasionally with our young son, Beth and I are in disagreement about the things we say,” says Gail. “Simple things like I’ll say ‘plaster’ and she’ll say ‘Band-aid,’ I’ll say ‘chips’ and she’ll say ‘fries’. He knows that he’s betwixt and between terms.
“Even things like ‘wee’ and ‘what’s the craic?’ There are phrases I would say that, in the mouth of someone who’s not from here, they sound ridiculous. You can hear people, and English speakers in particular, trying to accommodate themselves, ‘Well, hello, what’s the craic?’ Or even words like ‘scundered’ or ‘jammy,’ or ‘dead on,’ all these things that I say quite often.”"

can you generate a data model for a test automation tool considering organizations, users, projects, goals (under projects), tests (under goals) and executions (of test cases). Each execution has a date and a passed or failed status.
answer:
Organizations have users.  A user can be a part of 1 or more projects.  A project has goals.  A goal can include one or more tests (test cases).  An execution of a test case is performed against a project goal and is marked as passed/failed.

Project - Organization - User

Goal - Project

Test - Goal

Execution - Test - Passed/Failed

prompt: How can I calculate the amount of variations on a 3x4 table?
answer:
There are 3 ways of calculating the number of variations for a 3x4 table:

1) Calculate the number of permutations: There are 3! = 6 permutations of 3 items

2) Count the number of combinations: There are 4! = 24 combinations of 4 items

3) Consider the 3x4 grid as a 2x2 grid with additional constraints: This leads to (3, 1) = 3 combinations, (3, 2) = 3 combinations, (4, 1) = 1 combination, (4, 2) = 1 combination
